definition[0]: to stop taking part in an activity, belonging to an organization etc, or to make someone do this
example[0]: A knee injury forced her to withdraw from the competition.
example[1]: calls for Britain to withdraw from the European Union
example[2]: Parents have the right to withdraw their children from religious education lessons if they wish.
definition[1]: to stop giving support or money to someone or something, especially as the result of an official decision
example[3]: One of the minority parties had withdrawn its support for Chancellor Kohl.
example[4]: Union members will vote on whether to withdraw their labour (=stop working).
example[5]: a government decision to withdraw funding
definition[2]: if you withdraw a threat, offer, request etc, you say that you no longer will do what you said
example[6]: After much persuasion he agreed to withdraw his resignation.
definition[3]: if you withdraw a remark, criticism, statement etc, you say that what you said earlier was completely untrue
example[7]: He refused to withdraw his remarks and was expelled from the Party.
example[8]: The newspaper has agreed to withdraw its allegations.
definition[4]: if a product or service is withdrawn, it is no longer offered for sale or use
example[9]: The drug has been withdrawn from the market for further tests.
note[2]: withdraw something from sale/from the market
definition[5]: if an army withdraws, or if it is withdrawn, it leaves a place
example[10]: the USA’s decision to withdraw 40,000 troops from western Europe
definition[6]: to leave a place, especially in order to be alone or go somewhere quiet
example[11]: We withdrew to the garden for a private talk.
definition[7]: to take money out of a bank account
example[12]: I’d like to withdraw £500 from my current account.
explanation[0]: In everyday English, people often say that someone takes or gets money out rather than withdraws it:
example[13]: Can we stop off at the bank? I need to get some money out.
definition[8]: if you withdraw your hand, arm, finger etc from somewhere, you move it from there to where it was before
example[14]: Claudia withdrew her hand from his.
definition[9]: to take an object out from inside something
example[15]: She withdrew a document from her briefcase.
definition[10]: to become quieter, less friendly, and only concerned about your own thoughts
example[16]: Many depressed people just withdraw into themselves.
example[17]: Ralph has withdrawn from the other kids.
example[18]: You can withdraw cash from ATMs in any town or city.
definition[11]: to remove something or take it back, often because of an official decision
example[19]: They offered her the job but then withdrew the offer after checking her references.
definition[12]: if a company withdraws a product or service, it stops making it available, either for a period of time or permanently
example[20]: Previous testing showed no safety problems, but the company decided to withdraw the product so the incidents could be investigated.
example[21]: The drug has been withdrawn from the market for further testing.
definition[13]: to say that something you said earlier was completely untrue
definition[14]: to no longer take part in something or to no longer belong to a particular organization
example[22]: The Bank of New York withdrew as a primary dealer of U.S. government securities.
example[23]: His decision to withdraw from active management was a blow to the company.
